nodes.bodyText: Could we put these in MetadataStoreDirectoryConstants class?
Resolved.

I think we use CamelCase for resource names:

"/clusters/{clusterName}/resources/{resourceName}/externalView"

Should we follow the Helix REST convention?

There are at least 2 naming conventions for helix-rest:
all lowercase: "/clusters/{clusterName}/instances/{instanceName}/healthreports"
camelCase: "/clusters/{clusterName}/propertyStore/{path}"

There are a lot of comparisons for naming conventions in rest api.
I personally like spinal-case because:

it feels right for URLs: URLs are case sensitive, best practice is to use lower case wherever possible
has better readability than camelCase, especially for a long URI.
camelCase is ineffective in contexts which are not case sensitive
etc..

I don't have a strong opinion. In fact, "-" is used for most public APIs. The only reason to go with camelCase is because Helix REST is already using it.
Since we plan on breaking this out into a separate module/service, I am fine with either unless others can make a case one way or the other.
Agreed.
Just do a new HashMap()? Why do you need to put an empty list here? You override it anyways?
CamelCase?
Same thought above.
Also add realm.isEmpty()?

If param realm is not set (ream == null), all sharding keys of the namespace are returned. My initial thought is, if ream.isEmpty(), it means query param ?ream= is set to empty, this empty realm does not exit so NOT_FOUND is returned.
I added comments to clear the confusion.
The comment helps. OK to resolve.
Why are we doing this for realm == null? Wouldn't this be considered an implicit behavior? Shouldn't we return notFound for the realm or bad arg exception?

I should have added more comments for this. This actually provides two options:

"/sharding-keys": returns all sharding keys in this namespace.
"/sharding-keys?realm=zk-0": this adds a filter and returns sharding keys of the realm zk-0
if we return early, this else won't be necessary.
Why does this show up as a new file? We already have this. Could you rebase from apache/zooscalability?

It looks like there are a few endpoints missing such as:
getAllNamespaces
getAllMappingUnderPath
getMetadataStoreRealm
etc..
Is there a reason these endpoints were left out? If they are unsupported, we could create the resource endpoints and but a TODO for them.

Right, theses APIs are unsupported in the implementation. I don't think it is meaningful to just put the endpoints that are unsupported, because:

response with status code 501 has to return, which is extra work and unnecessary
can not test the endpoints in the unit tests

My plan is to create an issue to track the left-over endpoints and complete it once the read operations are implemented. It will only take 1 ~ 2 days to complete the left-over endpoints.
